intro: Greeneocharis circumscissa var. hispida, commonly known as the hispid bristly bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, bristly stems and leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically blue or violet in color. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Its unique morphology and adaptability make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
